utterances: A strategic weapon that attacked Japan would have far more impact on the American economy than a weapon that had virtually obliterated Alaska.
There's no question that we're talking about fellow Americans when we talk about Alaska.

But when you talk about strategic importance, the importance of Japan and South Korea to the American economy as a whole is vastly greater than that of Alaska or any small portion of the Pacific Northwest.
Cordesman says an attack on South Korea or Japan by North Korea could affect global trade and stock markets in all the economic powerhouses of Asia and America.
It undoubtedly would trigger a military response as well, says Jonathan Pollack, a professor of Asian and Pacific Studies at the Naval War College.
Mr.
Nissen was on the FDA advisory panel.
He started the discussion that led to the recommendation of a warning label for drugs like Adderall, Strateera, Ritalin, and Concerta.
On occasion, wondering whether I was too hungry to sleep or too sleepy to eat and being too exhausted to see my way through the next day.
But you get up and do it, anyway.
So reporters appreciate anyone who makes their job easier or more interesting, such as the candidate who travels in a bus, and now an airplane, that he calls…
The Straight Talk Express.
ABC senior political correspondent Jake Tapper covered John McCain's primary contest with then-Governor George W.
Bush for Salon.com in 2000.
McCain fed reporters a stream of quotable one-liners that often tweaked his fellow Republicans, sealing his reputation as a maverick.
Tapper, like McCain, is back on the trail this year.
John McCain's life is basically a press availability.
Between campaign stops, McCain ambles the length of the bus to reporters, plops down and invites them to fire away.
At a certain point, you're like okay, Senator McCain, you know, we need to write our stories now.
So if you don't mind going back up to the front…
McCain's become a bit more reserved, but he's still accessible.

When the senator was aggrieved by a New York Times story earlier this year that suggested an inappropriately cozy relationship with a female lobbyist, he called a press conference and gritted through every single question reporters had to ask.
Anything else?
Thank you.
Thank you all very much.
Thanks.
McCain wins points being accessible in good times and bad, and the Times took heat for its anonymously sourced story.
So McCain is a media favorite.
But - and this is a key but - so is Barack Obama, if for very different reasons.
Obama is fresh.
Another way to say that is that he's still largely unknown to reporters.
He's just been in the U.S.
Senate three-and-a-half years.
What they do know is that he's an extraordinary orator who can electrify crowds.
Yet for the media, Obama's not especially accessible.
Mark Silva's been covering the campaign for the Chicago Tribune.
With Obama, it's more the story of the man than the man himself.
He's had an amazing trajectory, coming from nowhere, launching what he, himself, called an improbable campaign at a time when it seemed that Hillary Clinton was, you know, unbeatable.
Obama's also run such a different campaign, truly based on the power of the Web, to organize a grassroots network to raise money, to draw young supporters and to energize black voters.
ABC's Jake Tapper says the new media favorite is starting to crowd out the old one.
The media loves new, and Barack Obama, warts and all, is new.
John McCain was new eight years ago, and he's not new anymore.
And I think that affects the general tone of the coverage.
In fact, one of the key questions about being a favorite of the press is whether that status truly does influence media coverage.
Just ask John McCain about the lobbyist Vicki Iseman or Barack Obama about the Reverend Jeremiah Wright.

The Boston Globe just published a lengthy look at investors in dilapidated public-housing developments who have ties to Obama, while the press is starting to look closely at the lobbyists who are running McCain's campaign.
But Gwen Ifill says media interest is not piqued solely by scandal in this cycle.
We are always biased in favor of a good story, and this year, Republicans and Democrats both have served up candidates which give us good stories.
How the press corps will feel about the winning candidate after next January 20th, well that's another question.
David Folkenflik, NPR News.
American Indians dressed in full regalia spent the weekend dancing and drumming in Washington, D.C.
Tribes from across the country are here for a national powwow.
The theme is honoring warriors past and present.
It is time.
Please make welcome the Kiowa War Mothers.
Six women wearing feathered war bonnets and beaded white leather dresses take center stage in a converted basketball arena.
The Kiowa War Mothers of Oklahoma all have children, husbands or brothers who have served in the United States Military.
Dorothy White Horse(ph) is one of the group's elders.
I have a granddaughter that served in Iraq.
I have a nephew that served in Desert Storm.
I have a very dear nephew that was killed in Vietnam.
His name was Donny Bear(ph).
Our first cousin that was killed in World War II, he's still living at Saint-Avons(ph) in France.
(Soundbite of victory dance)
When I'm doing the victory dance, that's the first one, when I'm dancing to that first song the way my mother - she passed away over 30 years ago.
She told is that that dance emulates if you will buy your teepee, and the warriors came back from some wars, you dance that.
You're just bouncing hard stiff.
So I take make myself and my mind to that time.
I try to imagine how my ancestors stand.
(Soundbite of chanting)
Our tribe is very patriotic.
And make no bones about it.
Our people support the war.
We support our president and all of his endeavors.
And to our Indians, if we drew our troops out right now, you just will put handprints on the back of their back and beadwork because that meant they got pushed out.
My brother wore a battle cape for they were on their - the hands are in the front because you meet the enemy face-to-face.
And this shows cowardice if you withdraw now.
Stay there until it's finished.
(Soundbite of war cry)
That was Dorothy White Horse, a member of the Kiowa War Mothers from Anadarko, Oklahoma.
While not all Native Americans share her support for the war, they are united behind the troops according to Harlan McKosato.
Studios, yes.
It can be hard to understand from the outside when what we hear about is this daily drumbeat of violence and especially an incident like today's.
It can be hard to picture how anything like daily life, college education, how that can go on normally.
I cannot say that it is normal.
It is never normal.
But many professors and students would say now, if we stop, the whole of the educational system is halted, then the whole society will dysfunction.
The percentage of students out of the whole youth population of Iraq is extremely high.
By stopping the classes around, then, you will see them all sitting at their homes.
And this creates trouble, of course.
So it wouldn't be right to stop the whole thing.

And even for the professors, they would try to keep a low profile but they wouldn't stop their research or if they are given the opportunity to give classes on the right basis, then they would do it right away.
Omar al-Farouk al-Damluji is professor emeritus of civil engineering at Baghdad University.
Thanks very much for talking with us.
Thank you very much.
The Wall Street Journal reports today that the arrests in Canada stem at least in part from an arrest in London last fall.
In October, Scotland Yard raided the London home of a young man named Younis Tsouli.
According to the Journal, Mr. Tsouli is well known in online Jihadist circles, and the web linked him to the Canadians.
Robert Block is one of the Wall Street Journal reporters who wrote the story.
And Mr. Block, tell us about Younis Tsouli.
Younis Tsouli had a fascinating on-screen name called Irhabi 007.
Irhabi is the Arabic word for terrorist, so he was this cyber-Jihadist that was taunting the Americans and several other law enforcement agencies around the world for years.
He was a hacker.
Probably his most famous exploit was hacking into the Arkansas Department of Transportation's server and posting Jihadist propaganda and videos of beheadings online.
And it was a case against a Danish-born Turkish man in Bosnia in a Swedish - on terrorism charges that accidentally revealed his identity as Younis Tsouli.
And soon after, the Brits raided his home, and they found his computers full of bomb-making guides and a little bit of digital video that looked like a surveillance video of landmarks in Washington.
And that connected him to this larger web in Canada, as well as two suspects in Atlanta.
To what extent was Younis Tsouli linked to any known terrorists, al-Qaida or others?
Well, he did a lot of propaganda and ran a lot of Web activities on behalf of Musab al-Zarqawi in Iraq.
How close he actually is - he's 22 years old.
It's unclear whether he's had any kind of terrorist training beyond his cyber-hijinks.
What is the link between Tsouli and the young men who've now been arrested in Canada?
Well, it seems that among the things that Irhabi 007 did was he organized chat rooms, and he took radicals that made their way to his Web site and he indoctrinated them further.
And he put them in touch with other people.
So, after the raid in London, what became clear is that the people in Toronto were talking to him.
The people in Atlanta were talking to him.
And the people in Atlanta were talking, it seems, to the people in Toronto.
And what became clear is this entire network of likeminded individuals had a place to go to share ideas, to plan.
There was no money or resources flowing around.
This was just conversation.
But that's the way the whole thing is morphing now, since Afghanistan has been closed down, and since they've managed to close up so many of the al-Qaida leadership over the last few years.
But your describing, now, investigations that involve Britain, Canada, the United States, Bosnia, Sweden, Denmark.
Lots of countries involved in all of this.

Right, and what's very interesting about this is when they all realized that they all had a piece of this, they all came together here in Washington, D.C., and they sat around, as I understand, a horseshoe table, and they all went around the table and they talked about what piece of the investigation they had.
And they strategized what was the best way to close this up in such a way - before, what they would do is they would rush out and arrest everyone, and anyone connected to the network would scatter.

And they strategically planned to roll this thing up, from the edges in, in such a way that they were able to - it finally culminated in the arrest over the weekend in Canada of the largest group, which was the Toronto cell.
